This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Judicial Commissioner
breach of art. 311 2  of the Constitution. The appeal is accordingly allowed

concepts.interpretation: Breach occurs due to lack of proper inquiry, including appointment of successive inquiry officers without proper justification or defect in prior inquiry, instead of disciplinary authority itself reconsidering the evidence and recording findings.
concepts.unlisted_description: Constitutional provision requiring reasonable opportunity before dismissal or removal from service

arguments.claim: Rule 15, on the face of it, really provides for one inquiry

arguments.claim: there is no provision in rule 15 for completely setting aside previous inquiries on the ground that the report of the Inquiring Officer or Officers does not appeal to the disciplinary Authority

anchor.surface_text: But there is no provision in rule 15 for completely setting aside previous inquiries on the ground that the report- of, the Inquiring Officer or Officers does not appeal to the disciplinary, Authority-

arguments.claim: The Disciplinary Authority has enough powers to reconsider the evidence itself and come to its own conclusion under rule 9

anchor.surface_text: The Disciplinary Authority has enough powers to reconsider the evidence itself and come to its own conclusion under rule 9.

arguments.claim: the rules do not contemplate an action such as was taken by the Collector on February 13, 1962

anchor.surface_text: In our view the rules do not contemplate an action such as was taken by the Collector on February 13, 1962.

arguments.claim: the Collector, instead of taking responsibility himself, was determined to get some officer to report against the appellant. The procedure adopted was not only not warranted by the rules but was harassing to the appellant

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the Collector, instead of taking responsibility himself, was determined to get some officer to report against the appellant. The procedure adopted was not only not warranted by the rules but was harassing to the appellant

arguments.claim: on the material on record a suspicion does arise, that the Collector was determined to get some Inquiry Officer to report against the appellant

anchor.surface_text: But it seems to us that on the material on record a suspicion does arise, that the Collector was determined to get some Inquiry Officer to report against the appellant.

arguments.claim: no proper inquiry has been conducted in the case and, therefore, there has been a breach of art. 311(2) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that no proper inquiry has been con- ducted in the case and, therefore, there has been a breach of art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

holdings.text: Rule 15, on the face of it, really provides for one inquiry but it may be possible if in a particular case there has been no proper enquiry because some serious defect has crept into the inquiry or some important witnesses were not available at the time of the inquiry or were not examined for some other reason, the Disciplinary Authority may ask the Inquiry Officer to record further evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that Rule 15, on the face of it, really provides for one inquiry but it may be possible if in a particular case there has been no proper enquiry because some serious defect has crept into the inquiry or some important witnesses were not available at the time of the inquiry or were not examined for some other reason, the Disciplinary Authority may ask the Inquiry Officer to record further evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of Rule 15 indicates single inquiry process with limited supplementation for defects, not fresh starts.

holdings.text: But there is no provision in rule 15 for completely setting aside previous inquiries on the ground that the report of, the Inquiring Officer or Officers does not appeal to the disciplinary Authority.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no provision in rule 15 for completely setting aside previous inquiries on the ground that the report- of, the Inquiring Officer or Officers does not appeal to the disciplinary, Authority-.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of explicit provision in Rule 15 for discarding prior inquiries merely due to disagreement by DA.

holdings.text: The Disciplinary Authority has enough powers to reconsider the evidence itself and come to its own conclusion under rule 9.

anchor.surface_text: The Disciplinary Authority has enough powers to reconsider the evidence itself and come to its own conclusion under rule 9.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 9 empowers DA to independently assess evidence without needing new inquiries.

holdings.text: In our view the rules do not contemplate an action such as was taken by the Collector on February 13, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In our view the rules do not contemplate an action such as was taken by the Collector on February 13, 1962.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeated appointment of new inquiry officers for fresh inquiry not foreseen in CCS CCA Rules.

holdings.text: It seems to us that the Collector, instead of taking responsibility himself, was determined to get some officer to report against the appellant. The procedure adopted was not only not warranted by the rules but was harassing to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the Collector, instead of taking responsibility himself, was determined to get some officer to report against the appellant. The procedure adopted was not only not warranted by the rules but was harassing to the appellant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sequence of events shows deviation from rules leading to harassment, indicating improper motive.

holdings.text: But it seems to us that on the material on record a suspicion does arise, that the Collector was determined to get some Inquiry Officer to report against the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: But it seems to us that on the material on record a suspicion does arise, that the Collector was determined to get some Inquiry Officer to report against the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Material on record, including multiple inquiries, raises suspicion of prejudice despite lower court view.

holdings.text: In the result we hold that no proper inquiry has been conducted in the case and, therefore, there has been a breach of art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: In the result we hold that no proper inquiry has been con- ducted in the case and, therefore, there has been a breach of art. 311 2  of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Improper successive inquiries violate Rule 15 and constitutional reasonable opportunity under Art. 311(2).

holdings.text: The appeal is accordingly allowed and the order dated June 4, 1962 quashed and it is declared that the appellant should be treated as still continuing in service. He should be paid his pay and allowances for the period he has been out of office.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Remedy follows from finding of constitutional breach.
